descendants.content:
@tj@home.tj-h.com @breadandcircuses@climatejustice.social

"Doing nothing" would mean "not issuing new drilling permits" (and the like). The US already had a lot of slack capacity: when fuel prices drop below certain levels, the capacity is offlined (and workers laid off, etc.). When prices rise to a level where pumping becomes profitable, again, the slack capacity is brought back online. All of which allows production numbers to go up without the government having to do anything.

account.note: Ex of Twitter (and many others before that) by way of mastodon.social (same user ID across a lot of platforms). Moved here because I like the ability to format posts and, sometimes, I need more than 500 characters ...plus there had been rumblings about mastodon.social getting widely defederated.

descendants.content:
@tj @breadandcircuses

Leaders are concerned with the economy first, climate change as an afterthought.

Until that mindset changes, the climate crisis will continue to worsen, bc bolstering the economy comes at the expense of preserving biodiversity.

We can have a healthy/growing economy or a healthy planet but not both bc they are opposing forces.

Analogous to only eating junk food and expecting a body to be healthy on that diet.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses

I'm no expert on US public transport, but just out of curiosity: Is the US even able to switch away from car-centered mobility within a reasonably short span of time?
I mean, building rail roads, digging metros, and creating the infrastructure to allow people to use bicycles etc. easily takes decades, given a political will exists.
